skill.name: pytdc
skill.description: Therapeutics Data Commons. AI-ready drug discovery datasets (ADME, toxicity, DTI), benchmarks, scaffold splits, molecular oracles, for therapeutic ML and pharmacological prediction.
skill.summary: Therapeutics Data Commons. AI-ready drug discovery datasets (ADME, toxicity, DTI), benchmarks, scaff...
skill.author: K-Dense-AI

security_audit.summary: This skill provides documentation and templates for PyTDC, a legitimate drug discovery dataset library. All 427 static findings are false positives caused by markdown code blocks containing Python examples (detected as shell backticks), scientific terminology (DRD2, GSK3B detected as C2 keywords), and molecular/cryptographic naming overlaps. No actual security risks present.

content.user_title: Access Drug Discovery Datasets with PyTDC
content.value_statement: Drug discovery researchers need standardized datasets for training ML models. PyTDC provides curated ADME, toxicity, and drug-target interaction datasets with proper train-test splits and evaluation oracles.
actual_capabilities: Load 60+ curated drug discovery datasets organized by therapeutic task
Apply scaffold, random, and cold-split strategies for proper ML evaluation
Evaluate molecules using 17+ oracle functions for property optimization
Run benchmark evaluations with standardized 5-seed protocols
Convert molecular representations between SMILES, SELFIES, and graph formats
Access drug-target interaction and drug-drug interaction datasets
limitations: Requires PyTDC Python package installation (pip install PyTDC)
Oracle functions need internet connection to download model weights on first use
Large datasets may require significant memory for loading
Does not include pre-trained ML models, only datasets and evaluation tools

use_cases.title: Train ADME Prediction Models
use_cases.description: Load Caco-2 permeability data with scaffold splits, train molecular property predictors, and evaluate with standard metrics.

use_cases.title: Evaluate Toxicity Predictors
use_cases.description: Access hERG, AMES, and DILI toxicity datasets with benchmark protocols to validate safety prediction models.

use_cases.title: Generate Novel Drug Candidates
use_cases.description: Use molecular oracles like GSK3B and DRD2 to guide generative models toward compounds with desired biological activity.

prompt_templates.title: Load ADME Dataset
prompt_templates.scenario: Starting a new ADME prediction project
prompt_templates.prompt: Help me load the Caco2_Wang dataset from TDC with scaffold splitting for training an intestinal permeability predictor.

prompt_templates.title: Run Benchmark Evaluation
prompt_templates.prompt: Show me how to evaluate my ADME model using the TDC benchmark group with the required 5-seed protocol.

prompt_templates.title: Use Molecular Oracles
prompt_templates.prompt: I want to evaluate generated SMILES strings using TDC oracles for QED, SA, and GSK3B properties. Show me the workflow.

prompt_templates.title: Drug-Target Interaction Modeling
prompt_templates.prompt: Load the BindingDB_Kd dataset with cold-drug splitting to ensure my model generalizes to unseen drug compounds.

output_examples.input: Load the AMES toxicity dataset and show me the data format
output: Dataset loaded with 7,255 compounds for mutagenicity prediction
Columns include Drug_ID, Drug (SMILES), and Y (binary toxicity label)
Scaffold split applied: 5,078 train, 725 validation, 1,452 test molecules

output_examples.input: Evaluate this molecule with the GSK3B oracle: CC(C)Cc1ccc(cc1)C(C)C(O)=O
output: This SMILES represents ibuprofen, not expected to inhibit GSK3B
Scores range from 0 to 1, with higher values indicating stronger predicted binding

best_practices: Use scaffold splits instead of random splits for realistic model evaluation on novel chemical scaffolds
Run benchmark evaluations with all 5 required seeds to report mean and standard deviation performance
Combine multiple oracles with weighted scoring for multi-objective molecular optimization
anti_patterns: Avoid random splits for production ADME models as they overestimate performance on similar molecules
Do not report single-seed benchmark results as they may not reflect true model variance
Avoid using oracles as ground truth labels for training since they are predictive models themselves

faq.question: What datasets are available in PyTDC?
faq.answer: PyTDC includes 60+ datasets covering ADME, toxicity, drug-target interactions, drug-drug interactions, and molecular generation tasks for therapeutic ML.

faq.question: What is a scaffold split and why use it?
faq.answer: Scaffold splits group molecules by chemical scaffold so test molecules have different core structures than training molecules, simulating real-world generalization.

faq.question: How do molecular oracles work?
faq.answer: Oracles are pre-trained models that score SMILES strings for properties like drug-likeness (QED), synthetic accessibility (SA), or target binding (GSK3B, DRD2).

faq.question: What is the 5-seed protocol for benchmarks?
faq.answer: TDC benchmarks require evaluation with 5 different random seeds to compute mean and standard deviation, ensuring robust performance comparisons.

faq.question: Can I use PyTDC with PyTorch Geometric or DGL?
faq.answer: Yes, TDC provides MolConvert utilities to transform SMILES into PyG graphs, DGL graphs, or other molecular representations like ECFP fingerprints.

faq.question: What is a cold-drug split for DTI prediction?
faq.answer: Cold-drug splits ensure test set drugs never appear in training, measuring how well models predict binding for completely novel drug compounds.
